facts.text: Appeal from judgment of High Court of Judicature at Bombay (Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.) dated 29th March 1950 in Suit No. 24 of 1950.
First respondent filed summary suit in Bombay High Court original side on 6th February 1950 against second respondent for recovery of Rs. 11,704-24 on promissory notes.

Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) established City Civil Court for Greater Bombay with jurisdiction over suits of civil nature not exceeding Rs. 10,000 (s.3), enhanced to Rs. 25,000 by notification under s.4 dated 20th January 1950.
Section 12 of the Act bars High Court jurisdiction over suits cognisable by City Civil Court.
Plaint claimed High Court jurisdiction alleging Act and notification ultra vires.
State of Bombay impleaded as defendant on its motion.
High Court held Act intra vires but s.4 ultra vires as delegation of legislative power; suit value exceeded Rs. 10,000 but notification inoperative, so High Court had jurisdiction.
Act aimed to relieve congestion on High Court original side by creating additional civil court.
High Court admitted plaint on 23rd February 1950 holding s.4 ultra vires.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay.
Whether in any event section 4 of the above Act is ultra vires the State Legislature.
Whether the Bombay High Court has jurisdiction to try the suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act intra vires under entry 1 List II (administration of justice, constitution and organisation of courts); includes power to confer general jurisdiction on courts constituted by province.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Government of India Act 1935, entry 1 List II; entry 53 List I, entry 2 List II are special powers supplementary to general power under entry 1 List II.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 4 is conditional legislation, not delegation; legislature fixed policy (initial Rs.10,000, max Rs.25,000), left timing to Provincial Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Queen v. Burah; distinguishes Jitendranath Gupta v. Province of Bihar.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pith and substance is constitution of court and administration of justice (List II); incidental encroachment on List I immaterial.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Ltd.; entry 4 List III (civil procedure).

respondent_arguments.text: Act ultra vires as confers jurisdiction on new court not only for List II matters but also List I (e.g. promissory notes, entry 28 List I).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Government of India Act 1935, entry 53 List I, entry 2 List II, entry 15 List III limit jurisdiction to respective lists.

respondent_arguments.text: Entry 1 List II excludes jurisdiction/powers, covered specifically by entry 2 List II only for List II matters.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Stewart v. Brojendra Kishore; Mulchand v. Raman distinguished.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 4 delegates legislative power to Provincial Government to decide jurisdiction up to Rs.25,000.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Jitendranath Gupta v. Province of Bihar.

court_reasoning.text: Administration of justice (entry 1 List II) includes jurisdiction and powers of courts; wide enough to confer general civil jurisdiction irrespective of subject-matter.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provincial Legislature can invest courts with power to try every civil matter unless barred by special legislation.

court_reasoning.text: Entries 53 List I, 2 List II confer special/additional jurisdiction/powers re specific list matters (e.g. barring ordinary courts, special orders); do not limit general power under entry 1 List II.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Practice pre-1935 continued; courts had general jurisdiction based on CPC s.9.

court_reasoning.text: Pith and substance of Act is constitution of court and administration of justice (List II); conferring general jurisdiction valid, incidental encroachment on List I (promissory notes) immaterial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act does not legislate on List I matters but invests court with general jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Section 4 valid conditional legislation; legislature determined policy (max Rs.25,000), delegated execution/timing to government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes true delegation; akin to Queen v. Burah (extension of territorial jurisdiction).

court_reasoning.text: High Court lacks jurisdiction per s.12; suit cognisable by City Civil Court.

holdings.text: Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 intra vires Provincial Legislature under entry 1 List II Government of India Act 1935.
Section 4 intra vires; conditional legislation, not invalid delegation.
Bombay High Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit; cognisable by City Civil Court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Ltd., Khulna
precedents_cited.relevance: Pith and substance doctrine; provincial money-lending law valid despite incidental effect on promissory notes (List I).
Conditional legislation valid; legislature fixes policy, delegates execution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jitendranath Gupta v. Province of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: True delegation (modification/re-enactment) invalid; unlike s.4 here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah
precedents_cited.relevance: Act intra vires under entry 1 List II.
Civil procedure excludes jurisdiction; rejected here.
Legislature can make law conditional on future determination.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Establishes City Civil Court with general civil jurisdiction up to specified pecuniary limit; bars High Court jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Distributive legislative powers; Lists I (entries 28,53), II (1,2), III (4,15).

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Courts have jurisdiction over all civil suits unless barred.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Aircraft Act, 1934
statutes_cited.relevance: Example of special powers conferred on courts (forfeiture).

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Bombay City Civil Court Act 1948 and s.4 held intra vires; notification effective; High Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit which is cognisable by City Civil Court; High Court decision reversed.
outcome.relief_granted: Suit to be tried by Bombay City Civil Court; High Court jurisdiction ousted.

key_quotes.text: "The expression administration of justice has a wide meaning, and includes administration of civil as well as criminal justice... are wide enough to include the power and jurisdiction of courts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on scope of entry 1 List II.

key_quotes.text: "Once it is determined that the pith and substance is money-lending, is the extent to which the federal field is invaded a material matter? ... No."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies pith and substance; incidental encroachment permitted.

key_quotes.text: "The proper Legislature has exercised its judgment as to place, person, laws, powers, and the result of that judgment has been to legislate conditionally as to all these things."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Queen v. Burah; validates s.4 as conditional legislation.
